context: Finally, the modest sample size and the lack of female subjects limit the generalizability of our findings. Nonetheless, the current study has numerous strengths that include the strict exclusion of known prevalent medical conditions that could influence neopterin levels, use of full-montage polysomnography to characterize SDB, consideration of age and obesity measures as possible confounders, and the ability to link neopterin to the degree of nocturnal hypoxemia and sleep stage distribution. The data provided herein extend prior observations that SDB is associated with low-grade systemic inflammation and more specifically provide first evidence for macrophage activation, which can be pathogenic for conditions such coronary artery disease. Although the clinical significance of elevated neopterin in SDB will require further investigation, it may hold clinical utility in identifying vulnerable SDB patients at risk for future cardiovascular morbidity. In conclusion, the results of the present study indicate that SDB is associated with levels of circulating neopterin, a marker of macrophage activation. Introduction Historically, the concept of purinergic signalling was proposed by Burnstock in 1972 after a purine nucleotide was shown to act as a neurotransmitter in non-adrenergic, non-cholinergic (NANC) nerves supplying the gut and urinary bladder. In fact, most of the early studies of purinergic signalling were focused on the autonomic nervous system and were largely concerned with rapid signalling in neurotransmission (for review, see Ref.).
